\newcommand{\K}{$\mathbb{K}$}

%%
%% The abstract is a short summary of the work to be presented in the
%% article.
\begin{abstract}
  We present CrlT - a verification tool for $k$-safety properties targetting selected smart-contract languages.
  Internally, the tool implements Cartesian reachability logic, which is a recently introduced logic
  for proving $k$-safety properties that has been designed to work with any deterministic programming language.
  CrlT is implemented on top of \K{} framework - a framework for developing formal semantics of programming languages
  - and reuses existing \K{}-based semantics of EVM, WASM, Plutus and Teal without major modifications.
  We report very low cost of development of CrlT - in the order of a few man-months -
  even as it targets real-world languages, thus demonstrating the benefits of strict separation of
  language semantics from tools.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}

In recent years, the formal methods community witnessed an increased interest in
formal verification of \emph{hyperproperties} \cite{ClarksonS08}.
In constrast with the usual \emph{trace properties}, which are predicates on traces,
hyperproperties are predicates on \emph{sets of traces}, which gives them an extra expressive power.
This power can be used for expressing functional properties (e.g. commutativity) as well as security properties
(e.g. information flow policies).
Among hyperproperties, the class of $k$-safety properties (aka $k$-safety hyperproperties)
has received some extra attention \cite{AgrawalB16,FinkbeinerHT19,SousaD16,CRL}.
Intuitively, a hyperproperty is $k$-safety (for a positive natural number $k$)
iff it prohibits the existence of a ``bad'' set of cardinality $k$ of executions;
the class of $1$-safety properties corresponds exactly to the well-known class of safety properties.
